text: - Ejenta means agent in Bengali
and our mission is to apply AI
and intelligent agent technology
to make healthcare accessible for all.
(light music)

I'm Rachna Dhamija, I'm the
founder and CEO of Ejenta.
- My name is Maarten Sierhuis
and I'm the CTO and co-founder of Egenta.
(light music)

- We are using intelligent
agent technology
that my co-founder developed at NASA
for remotely monitoring astronauts.
An intelligent agent essentially
it's an autonomous software program

and it's able to sense
data from its environment,
it's able to reason, it's able to learn,
and then it can take action autonomously
on behalf of its users.
So, let's say a patient has a weight scale

and a blood pressure monitor,
maybe in an activity tracker.
That agent is always monitoring that data.

And then trying to predict
the patient's health based
on the data that we collect in the home

and then based on data
that we also collect
from the patient's medical record.
Then the intelligent agents can reach out
to a healthcare provider.

For example, to give the
health provider an alert
that a patient might need help
or their health is deteriorating.

And we give of every
patient on our platform
their own intelligent agent

that's continuously
monitoring data about them,

that learns about them,
that predicts their health,

and that can help their
health providers to intervene
before a negative event happens.
(light music)

Maarten and I were both going
through were similar things
with our families.
My dad was pretty ill and far away
and it was hard to take care of him
and his mother had the same issue.

She had a chronic condition
and was in the Netherlands.

So, we ended up talking
about that problem a lot.
So, Maarten had told me a joke.

- It would be easy if our
parents could wear space suits

because then I could
monitor them at a distance
just like our astronauts.
- And then we realized actually we have
all of the technology

that is in a space suit
that we could bring

in our parents' homes
and make it a reality.

So, we're kind of turning the
healthcare system on its head
by making care continuous

and predictive and preventative,
rather than episodic.

- Brahms is actually a
multi-agent programming

and modeling human
behavior modeling language.
You can both simulate things in Brahms,
so simulate human behavior,

and then also implement those
simulations as real systems.
Brahms is named after the composer
and I always say work is like a symphony,
well rehearsed, but always different.
It had its origins

in actually studying workflow
systems in organizations.

In the early 2000s is when
we started actually modeling
and researching the astronauts
from the Apollo missions on the moon.
And then I really started to understand

how this relationship between
people in mission control

on Earth were collaborating
and coordinating the work
on the moon with the astronauts.

When knowledge becomes important
is when things go wrong.
And then it was the key moment was then
how do you build systems

that can actually incorporate
that type of knowledge
and can react to things

that are not something
that happens every day?

It's not about all the
things that go right.
That is the simple part.

It's about what does the
system do when it goes wrong?

Then we got a request from
JPL, Jet Propulsion Laboratory,

to help them with the
design of mission operations

for the MER mission, for
spirit and opportunity on Mars.
We started with moving the simulation
to a real Mars-like environment

and we used the Mars Desert
Research Station in Utah
to create an environment where we lived
like we would live on Mars

with robots, communication
back to mission control.

Mission control wanted
to monitor the health
of the astronauts in the space suit
while we were in the desert.
So, we built this agent that would

with sensors in the space
suit for our astronauts,
monitor that and sent that information
to the doctor in mission control.

That research actually
led to mission control

for the International
Space Station asking us

to use this technology to
help them create automation

in mission control and
it's still running 24/7
for the International Space Station.

I have moved on to bring
this technology to Earth
and to the real world
and for me that is healthcare.
I wanna solve problems that have an impact
for humankind here on Earth.
(light music)
- So we approached NASA
for a license agreement and then developed
our proof of concept, I think that took
about six months to a year.

Introducing new technology to
healthcare takes a long time
because you have to prove,

you have to validate that
it works and that it's safe.
So, we've gone through a number
of clinical trials and we're now

at the stage where we're
deploying and scaling.
- I always had this feeling from
if I can create a computer system running
and mission control for NASA,

I could get it running in
somebody's home, right?

But that still, that was a long
journey to get that working.
There was this distinct moment
when our first patient got online

with a real clinical trial
with a healthcare organization.

And that was a pivotal
moment because that proved

to me that we could actually
do it and it actually worked.
It was actually in the hands of somebody
somewhere in the United States

and we were getting
data and collecting data

and helping that patient
stay home healthy.
- And now we're trying to really scale

and grow the company
and make this a reality.
(light music)
We're working with Trish

which is the Translational
Research Institute

for Space Health at
Baylor College of Medicine
and working closely with NASA as well
to take what we've done,

which started off with
Maarten's technology
for monitoring astronauts in space.

We brought it back to Earth
and now we're bringing it back
to space for long duration space flight.

So, if you look at one of
the problems we're solving

in long duration space flight,
you have an astronaut who's
in a really contained environment.

He's in deep space, doesn't
have a lot of contact
with his family, or if he does,
there's a 20-minute time delay.
And so there are a lot
of behavioral issues that arise from that.

There are a lot of
potential impacts on health.

But if you think about the
patient who's isolated at home,
the issues can be very similar.

Advances that we make
in helping astronauts

for a long duration space
flight do have implications
for developing technology at home.
(light music)

- I still feel that AI
is at the early stage.
And one example I can give
is just how we communicate through voice
with AI agents at the moment.
Humans have conversations.

Humans have history and
memory about a conversation.

It's not just, I ask a question
and you give an answer.

It's just the way we interact
as humans is so fluent
and is based on common ground.

And this common ground is
what I think AI systems still,
they don't have this common ground

and so therefore, the interaction
between me and my agent
is still very awkward.

And to make this into the holy
grail that I have in my mind,
we need to develop a lot more capability.
- So, we're just in the early phases now
where we're deploying our technology
with patients with chronic conditions.

The end goal is to make
this available to everybody.

So not just people who
are chronically ill,
not just the sickest of us,

but to people who are
healthy to prevent them
from getting ill in the first place.
(light music)
